column6: Astun Data Services provide a range of geographic data as web services for consumption as base mapping within web mapping and desktop GIS applications. The use of Astun Data Services provides a cost effective and resource free alternative to translating, storing, updating and serving base mapping data to internal and public users.Map data services available include:Ordnance Survey Premium Data (MasterMap, VectorMap Local, Meridian and Strategi)Ordnance Survey OpenData (VectorMap District, Meridian and Strategi)OpenStreetMap (GB coverage in British National Grid)Map data is available in British National Grid (BNG) as an Open Geospatial Consortium Web Map Service (OGC WMS) or as Tile Service with 15 levels of zoomOpenData services includeEdubaseNHS ChoicesLocal Government Boundaries and Electoral Boundaries (BoundaryLine) enhanced with data from OpenlyLocal and UKWhipNeighbourhood Crime incident data from police.uk aggregated to neighbourhood boundariesOpenData feeds are syndicated and served as an Open Geospatial Consortium Web Feature Service (OGC WFS)
column7: - This service provides geographic data as web services. Among the geographic data they "proxy" are open data sources such as the Ordnance Survey open data products. I would not say this makes them an actual open data service.

column6: In its Open Data White Paper "Unleashing the Potential" the Government outlined its serious intent to make public sector data more available to businesses and to the public. The pinnacle of availability is considered to be a 5 star 'linked data' rating which indicates that the data is both available and is already linked to other data sources; allowing it to be easily exploited to generate insight. It may not be practical or good value for money to attempt to make all of an organisation's data meet this standard. To make meaningful progress, each department will need to understand where their gaps are, the ones to focus on that will drive the greatest value and the practical steps they can take to resolve these gaps. column6: CKAN is a powerful data management system to publish open government data. Some core characteristics make it a perfect choice for any public sector institution: CKAN.org is a community-based open source project and the source code is AGPL v3 licensed. This open approach assures users maximum room for manoeuvre in the future, protects their investment and prevents vendor lock-in. CKANäó»s architecture is highly modular: components and extensions allow the system to be customized to your needs. Developers can easily extend its functionality without the need to understand the whole system. In addition, CKAN offers a rich RESTful API (using JSON representations) that exposes all of CKANäó»s core functionality to external client applications using only open web standards. CKAN supports publishers and data re-users alike. At Zennor Consulting we provide specialist advice, by security cleared consultants with a track record of delivery within central and local government for organisations looking to adopt or integrate cloud based solutions, which are increasingly being supplied by G-Cloud suppliers. Business Analysis: At the very early stages we can assist with the project concept, seeking to ensure your concept is "cloud ready" and that important issues are understood, such as the business impact levels of data and any pre-existing platforms that might need to be integrated or supported.  This leads on to requirements gathering, whilst both the spirit of G-Cloud and Agile ways of working do not embrace writing long lists of requirements up-front, there are still some important key criteria to get down on paper, such as business impact levels, estimated usage, integration requirements or "must have" functionality.Project Selection and Specification: Selection of providers via G-Cloud is becoming more straightforward, however we can still help in running sifting through the service definitions, accreditation status and pricing tables in order to help with long listing, short listing and any detail required to identify the provider that most suits your project needs.Design Authority: The cloud and G-Cloud open up a lot of opportunities regarding solutions, but the architecture within cloud solutions still needs to be defined correctly for any specific project and this is another area where we can help. This might involve meshing two or more cloud providers together, such as CDN and Web Hosting, designing in service separation so that services degrade gracefully under load or failure, or using cloud based testing and monitoring services to ensure the service scales as required. Whilst the cloud is often cited as a great way to ensure scalability (which it certainly is) you have to "get it right" and that's what we do.Design and Development: Security is always important and the move to cloud poses some new challenges, least of all persuading the doubters. We have a solid understanding of the government security frameworks and experience in delivering pragmatic solutions that ensure accreditors remain happy. We are vendor neutral, but strongly support Open Source Software (OSS) and are keen to both leverage and deliver Open Data. Transition Management: Moving onto the cloud will be exciting and challenging, we work with you to make sure that no one and nothing gets left behind, ensuring that you have plan to cover issues such as data migration, user training, testing, service changeover and decommissioning. This should also cover important issues such as planning for any future "off boarding" to make best use of the supplier diversity and flexibility offered by G-Cloud.Some recent feedback from a supplier we worked with on a high profile cloud project was "You asked us some very hard questions, but you also had ideas and solutions for how we could respond"
